metadata.title: Denney Kitfox
aws::graph::propositions: Derivative Designs of the Denney Kitfox
Belite Aircraft is a company based in Wichita, Kansas.
Belite Aircraft has produced the Belite Aircraft Superlite since early 2009.
The Belite Aircraft Superlite is a derivative of the Kitfox Lite single-seat ultralight design.
Belite Aircraft extensively redesigned the Kitfox Lite aircraft.
Belite Aircraft incorporated carbon fiber reinforced polymer wings in the redesign.
Belite Aircraft incorporated carbon fiber reinforced polymer struts in the redesign.
Belite Aircraft incorporated carbon fiber reinforced polymer spars in the redesign.
Belite Aircraft incorporated carbon fiber reinforced polymer ribs in the redesign.
The redesign lowered the empty weight to 245 lb (111 kg).
Belite Aircraft acquired the production rights to the Kitfox Lite.
Belite Aircraft acquired the tooling for the Kitfox Lite in March 2009.
Belite Aircraft acquired existing parts for the Kitfox Lite in March 2009.
Belite Aircraft acquired manufacturing rights to the Kitfox Lite in March 2009.
Belite Aircraft agreed to rebrand the airplane as a condition of the transaction.
The rebranding was to prevent confusion with the larger, two-place light sport Kitfox.
The Belite Aircraft Superlite has a metal airframe.
The Belite Aircraft Superlite is covered in poly-fiber fabric.
The Apollo Fox is based upon the Kitfox in Europe.
The Aeropro Eurofox is based upon the Kitfox in Europe.
The Apollo Fox has Junkers flaps.
The Apollo Fox has folding wings.
The Aeropro Eurofox has Junkers flaps.
The Aeropro Eurofox has folding wings.

text:
### Derivative designs
Since early 2009, Belite Aircraft, a new company based in Wichita, Kansas has produced the Belite Aircraft Superlite derivative of the Kitfox Lite single-seat ultralight design. Belite extensively redesigned the aircraft to incorporate carbon fiber reinforced polymer wings, struts, spars and ribs, lowering the empty weight to 245 lb (111 kg).
Belite Aircraft "has acquired the production rights to a previously designed aircraft, the Kitfox Lite" and has "acquired the tooling, existing parts and manufacturing rights to the aircraft in March of 2009. As a condition of the transaction, they agreed to rebrand the airplane to prevent any confusion with the larger, two-place light sport Kitfox". It has a metal airframe and is covered in poly-fiber fabric.
In Europe, the Apollo Fox and Aeropro Eurofox are based upon the Kitfox, with their Junkers flaps and folding wings.
